head.supplied: Memo ¶ ¶ I have this day visited the Botanical Garden for the purpose of taking delivery of the property thereof. The Govt. Botanist, owing to indisposition, was unable to attend, but he had instruct...

div.p: From Alexander Wallis to James Francis
D73/15545, unit 746, VPRS 3991 inward registered correspondence, VA 475 Chief Secretary's Department, Public Record Office, Victoria.

I have this day visited the Botanical Garden for the purpose of taking delivery of the property thereof. The Govt. Botanist, owing to indisposition, was unable to attend, but he had instructed Mr. Luhmann, his clerk, to meet me and hand over the said property. I inspected the various articles herein enumerated and found everything correct. Every article of house furniture, every tool, &c, contained in the garden are given, but not the plants in the conservatories, and nurseries, are the seed in the seed-room, all of which still remain in the custody of the gardeners in charge. The keys herewith belong to the late Director's House, and to the laboratory, but as the latter building is still occupied by Mr. Rummel, the operator, I have instructed Mr. Luhmann to see that he / Mr Rummel / remove, and then to lock the building and lodge the key in this office. There are a few letter and other books, also a copying press in the office which, if permitted, the Govt. Botanist would like to retain. There are also in the nurseries a number of seedling trees which, I think, should be at once transferred to the State Nursery and planted out in Nursery rows, that they may be ready for distribution next season. I will hand a list of these to Mr. Hodgkinson tomorrow. The Govt. Botanist has caused the Botanical Library and some of his private property to be lodged in the Museum.
